sentences.text: Incumbent president Alexander Lukashenko has won every Elections in Belarus|presidential election since 1994, with all but the first being deemed by international monitors as neither Free and fair election|free nor fair. Aside from Lukashenko, there were four candidates on the ballot. Three of them represented pro-government parties. The fourth candidate, Hanna Kanapatskaya, was the only formally independent candidate, but opposition figures accused her of being a Dummy candidate|stooge, which her supporters have denied.<ref name=":0" />

references.text: <ref name=":1"/> Prior to the elections, independent media was closed down or forced to operate from abroad.<ref name=":0">{{Cite news |last=Allnutt |first=Luke |date=2025-01-24 |title=Could Belarus's Presidential Election Be Lukashenka's Last? |url=https://www.rferl.org/a/belarus-election-lukashenka-tsikhanouskaya/33285221.html |publisher=Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty }}</ref>

sentences.text: Following exit poll results indicating Lukashenko's decisive victory, the election was described as a Sham election|sham by critics. Lukashenko faced no serious challenge on the ballot from the other candidates and received over 87% of the vote.

references.text: <ref>{{Cite web |last=Svirnovskiy |first=Gregory |date=2025-01-26 |title=Lukashenko wins 'sham' election in Belarus with 87.6 percent of vote |url=https://www.politico.eu/article/alexander-lukashenko-wins-sham-election-in-belarus/ |access-date=2025-01-26 |website=POLITICO}}</ref>

<ref>{{Cite news |last=Higgins |first=Andrew |date=2025-01-26 |title=Belarus's Strong-Arm Leader, Aleksandr Lukashenko, Cruises to Re-election |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2025/01/26/world/europe/belarus-lukashenko-re-election.html |access-date=2025-01-26 |work=The New York Times |language=en-US |issn=0362-4331}}</ref>

<ref>{{Cite web |date=2025-01-26 |title=Belarus strongman set to win a 7th term in an election the opposition calls a farce |url=https://apnews.com/article/belarus-lukashenko-election-crackdown-opposition-putin-ae937352a1340ad5ca02ab55744487e0 |access-date=2025-01-26 |website=AP News |language=en}}</ref>

<ref>{{cite news |last1=Trevelyan |first1=Mark |title=Putin ally Lukashenko declared winner of Belarus vote that West calls a charade |url=https://www.reuters.com/world/europe/lukashenko-pockets-massive-win-belarus-election-scorned-by-west-2025-01-27/ |work=Reuters |date=27 January 2025}}</ref>

sentences.text: 2020 Belarusian protests|Mass protests alleging widespread vote-rigging erupted after incumbent president Alexander Lukashenko was declared the winner of the 2020 Belarusian presidential election|2020 presidential election. He had won every Elections in Belarus|presidential election since 1994, with all but the first being deemed by international monitors as neither Free and fair election|free nor fair. Opposition figure Sviatlana Tsikhanouskaya, who claimed to have won the election, went into exile.<ref name="BBC_BY_exiled_leader_peaceful_rallies" /> Tsikhanouskaya formed government-in-exile institutions consisting of the Coordination Council (Belarus)|Coordination Council, created in August 2020,<ref name="BBC_BY_exiled_leader_peaceful_rallies" /> and the United Transitional Cabinet of Belarus|United Transitional Cabinet, created in August 2022.<ref name="RFERL_second_anniversary" /><ref name="DW_BY_opposition_leader_says" />

references.text: <ref name=":1">{{cite news |last1=Vasilyeva |first1=Nataliya |title=His Opponents Sidelined, Lukashenko Is Set for a 7th Term in Belarus |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2025/01/25/world/europe/belarus-election-lukashenko.html |work=The New York Times |date=25 January 2025}}</ref>

<ref>{{cite news |title=Belarus' Lukashenko to Run for Seventh Presidential Term in 2025 |url=https://www.voanews.com/a/belarus-lukashenko-to-run-for-seventh-presidential-term-in-2025/7502067.html |publisher=Voice of America |date=25 February 2024 }}</ref>

sentences.text: On 17 August 2020, Lukashenko stated that the next presidential election could be held earlier than 2025 if a new constitution were to be adopted. Tsikhanouskaya stated that she was ready to lead a transitional government and to hold early elections under international supervision. Lukashenko said that he would resign if a new constitution was adopted.

references.text: <ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.rferl.org/a/calls-for-strikes-in-belarus-keep-pressure-on-lukashenka-after-huge-minsk-rally/30787556.html|title=Heckled And Jeered, Lukashenka Says New Election Could Be Held After Constitutional Changes|publisher=Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty|date=17 August 2020 |access-date=17 August 2020|archive-date=12 January 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210112152820/https://www.rferl.org/a/calls-for-strikes-in-belarus-keep-pressure-on-lukashenka-after-huge-minsk-rally/30787556.html|url-status=live}}</ref>

sentences.text: On 23 October 2024, the Central Election Commission of Belarus (CEC) announced that the election would be held on 26 January 2025, with a potential second round to be held on 12 February.

references.text: <ref>{{cite web |title=Belarus to Hold Next Presidential Election on Jan. 26 |website=The Moscow Times |url=https://www.themoscowtimes.com/2024/10/23/belarus-to-hold-next-presidential-election-on-jan-26-a86783 |access-date=23 October 2024 |date=23 October 2024}}</ref>

<ref name="round2">{{cite news |title=Belarus presidential election: Who's taking on Lukashenko, does it matter? |url=https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2025/1/26/belarus-presidential-election-whos-taking-on-lukashenko-does-it-matter |access-date=26 January 2025 |publisher=Al Jazeera |date=26 January 2025}}</ref>

sentences.text: On 6 November 2024, the Viasna Human Rights Centre reported that Belarusian authorities had started a wave of arrests with over a hundred people detained in a week, many linked to online chats, at a time when Belarusian prisons were already overcrowded.

references.text: <ref>{{Cite web |url=https://kyivindependent.com/belarus-cracks-down-ahead-of-january-election-over-100-people-detained/ |title=Belarus cracks down ahead of January election, over 100 people detained |website=The Kyiv Independent |date=2024-11-07 |access-date=2024-11-07}}</ref>

sentences.text: On 23 October 2024, the same day that the CEC announced the election, Tsikhanouskaya, the United Transitional Cabinet, and the Coordination Council stated that they would consider the election to be invalid unless all human rights in Belarus#Political dissidents and prisoners|political prisoners were released, participation by all Belarusians regardless of residence was implemented, and other conditions such as human rights in Belarus#Freedom of association|freedom of assembly and equal access to the media were fulfilled. Tsikhanouskaya later called the vote a "farce" and called for a boycott, but advised against protests "until the real moment of possibility".<ref name="round2"/>

references.text: <ref name="Tsikhanouskaya_joint_statement">{{cite Q|Q131857853|url-status=live}}</ref>

<ref name="s468">{{cite web |last=Jochecová |first=Ketrin |date=2024-10-23 |title=Belarus announces date for Lukashenko's next election win |url=https://www.politico.eu/article/belarus-announces-date-for-lukashenkos-re-election/ |access-date=2025-01-24 |newspaper=Politico}}</ref>

<ref name="q655">{{cite web |website=EU Today |date=2024-10-23 |title=Belarus Sets Presidential Election Date for January 2025 |url=https://eutoday.net/belarus-sets-presidential-election-date-for-january-2025/ |access-date=2025-01-24}}</ref>

<ref>{{cite news |title=Belarus election is poised to extend the 30-year rule of 'Europe's last dictator' |url=https://apnews.com/article/belarus-election-lukashenko-crackdown-e9fdb16a721022364cf5108cf5e94762 |access-date=24 January 2025 |publisher=Associated Press |date=24 January 2025}}</ref>

sentences.text: In November, Estonian foreign minister Margus Tsahkna stated that the election would not be recognised by Estonia, saying it would not meet democratic standards. On 9 January 2025, Małgorzata Kidawa-Błońska, Marshal of the Senate of Poland|Marshal of the Senate of Poland|Polish Senate, stated that the chamber would not recognise the election. On 22 January, the European Parliament called for the European Union (EU) and EU member states to refuse to recognise Lukashenko as president after the vote.

references.text: <ref name="EER_EE_not_recognize_charade">{{cite Q|Q131862682|url-status=live}}</ref>
<ref name="PolskieRadio_PL_not_recognize_upper_house">{{cite Q|Q131862725|url-status=live}}</ref>
<ref name="EuroParl_EP_denounces_upcoming">{{cite Q|Q131857947|url-status=live}}</ref>

sentences.text: Outgoing US Secretary of State Antony Blinken said the election cannot be free or fair in an "environment where censorship is ubiquitous and independent media outlets no longer exist". The European Commission also called the vote "a total sham". A joint EU statement rejecting the legitimacy of the election was blocked by Hungary.

references.text: <ref name="round2"/> Parliamentary Assembly of the Council of Europe rapporteur Ryszard Petru said on 24 January that the election was lacking in debate, free choice and transparency, which meant that it "cannot and will not meet internationally recognised standards of fairness and legitimacy".<ref>{{cite news |title=Belarus' Lukashenko Is a Shoo-In for His Seventh Election as President |url=https://www.themoscowtimes.com/2025/01/24/belarus-lukashenko-is-a-shoo-in-for-his-seventh-election-as-president-a87722 |access-date=24 January 2025 |work=The Moscow Times |date=24 January 2025}}</ref>

<ref name="euronews"/> On 25 January, EU foreign policy chief Kaja Kallas also called the election a "sham".<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.france24.com/en/live-news/20250126-lukashenko-set-to-extend-30-year-rule-in-belarus |title=Polls open in Belarus with Lukashenko set to extend 30-year rule |date=26 January 2025 |access-date=26 January 2025 |publisher=France 24}}</ref>

<ref>{{Cite news |title=Hungary Blocks Joint EU Statement On Presidential Elections In Belarus – Sources |url=https://www.rferl.org/a/belarus-hungary-kallas-european-union-presidential-election/33289953.html |access-date=2025-01-27 |work=RadioFreeEurope/RadioLiberty |language=en}}</ref>

sentences.text: On 25 February 2024, the day of 2024 Belarusian parliamentary election|parliamentary elections, Alexander Lukashenko announced his intention to run for a seventh term in 2025. His candidacy, which was submitted by an initiative group, was accepted by the CEC on 29 October. On the same day, the CEC rejected the candidacies of {{ill|For Freedom (Belarus)|lt=For Freedom|be|За Свабоду (рух)|be-tarask|За Свабоду|ru|За свободу (движение)}} movement leader {{ill|Yuri Gubarevich|be|Юрый Іванавіч Губарэвіч|be-tarask|Юры Губарэвіч|ru|Губаревич, Юрий Иванович}}, citing "violation of the procedure for submitting documents", and Aliaxandar Drazdou. On 4 November, two more candidates were rejected, Diana Kovaleva and Viktor Kulesh, while three other candidates were allowed to begin collecting signatures to support their candidacies, thereby taking the number of  candidates with this status to seven. These include Sergei Syrankov of the Communist Party of Belarus|Communist Party, Oleg Gaidukevich of the Liberal Democratic Party of Belarus|Liberal Democratic Party, and former Ministry of Internal Affairs (Belarus)|Interior Ministry spokesperson {{ill|Olga Chemodanova|be|Вольга Мікалаеўна Чамаданава|be-tarask|Вольга Чамаданава}}. On 12 November, Chemodanova and {{ill|Siarhei Bobrykau|be|Сяргей Валянцінавіч Бобрыкаў}} dropped their candidacies and endorsed Lukashenko. Following the early December deadline to get 100,000 signatures, the CEC said five candidates were approved to stand:

sentences.text: Syrankov supported the rebuilding of monuments to Joseph Stalin and the criminalisation of LGBTQ rights in Belarus|LGBT activities in Belarus. His campaign slogan was "Not instead of, but together with Lukashenko!". In an interview with the BBC, Syrankov said "there is no alternative to Alexander Lukashenko as the leader of our country", adding that "we are taking part in the election with the president's team". He also called Lukashenko the "main Communist" in Belarus. Likewise, Gaidukevich said "it's obvious that Lukashenko will win" and urged other candidates to "make Lukashenko's enemies nauseous". Alexander Khizhnyak pledged to prevent a "repeat of disturbances" in the 2020 presidential election, while Hanna Kanapatskaya presented herself as the "only democratic alternative to Lukashenko" and pledged for the release of political prisoners while warning supporters against "excessive initiative". She added "I do not fight with police officers because it is a crime. But that doesn't mean I support the policies of the current leadership of the country."

sentences.text: According to an exit poll shown on state television, Lukashenko won with 88% of the vote, with 82% turnout. EU foreign policy chief Kaja Kallas called the election a "blatant affront to democracy". Exiled Belarus opposition leader Sviatlana Tsikhanouskaya called the election "a senseless farce, a Lukashenko ritual".

references.text: <ref>{{Cite web |last= |date=January 26, 2025 |title=Lukashenko on track to win with 88% in Belarus election scorned by West as a sham |url=https://www.reuters.com/world/europe/west-cries-foul-over-belarus-election-lukashenko-eyes-seventh-term-2025-01-26/ |archive-url= |archive-date= |access-date=January 26, 2025 |website=Reuters}}</ref>

sentences.text: The CEC did not conduct overseas voting for the election, citing a decrease in the number of diplomatic staff posted abroad. The decision disenfranchised many exiled critics and others who had left the country since 2020. Early voting began on 21 January, with turnout reaching 41.81% by 26 January. Opposition groups said that ballot boxes used in early voting were left unguarded until election day, allowing irregularities to take place. The Belarusian government invited the Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe to monitor the vote, but the latter was unable to send observers as the invitation was issued only ten days before the election. On March 25, 2025, Alexander Lukashenko was sworn in for a seventh term as President of Belarus after winning 85.7% of the vote in the election.

references.text: <ref>{{cite news |title=Belarus will not open overseas polling stations in this yearʼs presidential election |url=https://babel.ua/en/news/114379-belarus-will-not-open-overseas-polling-stations-in-this-year-s-presidential-election |access-date=26 January 2025 |publisher=Babel |date=10 January 2025}}</ref>

sentences.text: Lukashenko was congratulated on his victory by Azerbaijani president Ilham Aliyev, Chinese president Xi Jinping, Egyptian president Abdel Fattah el-Sisi, Equatoguinean president Teodoro Obiang Nguema Mbasogo, Georgian president Mikheil Kavelashvili, Ghanan president John Mahama, Indian prime minister Narendra Modi, Iranian president Masoud Pezeshkian, Kazakh president Kassym-Jomart Tokayev, Kenyan president William Ruto, Kuwaiti emir Mishal Al-Ahmad Al-Jaber Al-Sabah, Kyrgyz president Sadyr Japarov, Laotian president Thongloun Sisoulith, Mongolian president Ukhnaagiin Khürelsükh, Nigerian president Bola Tinubu, North Korean leader Kim Jong Un, Omani sultan Haitham bin Tariq, Pakistani prime minister Shehbaz Sharif, Qatari emir Tamim bin Hamad Al Thani, Russian president Vladimir Putin, Saudi king Salman of Saudi Arabia|Salman, Serbian president Aleksandar Vucic, Sri Lankan president Anura Kumara Dissanayake, Tajik president Emomali Rahmon, Thai prime minister Paetongtarn Shinawatra, Turkmen president Serdar Berdimuhamedow, Uzbek president Shavkat Mirziyoyev, Ecuadorian president Daniel Noboa, Emirati president Mohamed bin Zayed Al Nahyan, Venezuelan president Nicolás Maduro, Vietnamese president Lương Cường, and he was also congratulated by several pro-Russian Moldovan politicians: former president and Party of Socialists of the Republic of Moldova|Party of Socialists leader Igor Dodon, fugitive oligarch Ilan Shor and Gagauzia|Gagauz governor Evghenia Guțul.
